There are lots of possible causes of lumps and growths.

Your symptoms might give you an idea of what’s causing it, but do not self-diagnose.

See a GP if you're worried or the lump is still there after 2 weeks.

Lumps anywhere on the body

Lump: Small, fleshy growth on the skin
Possible cause: Skin tag

Lump: Soft, squashy lump that moves
Possible cause: Lipoma

Lump: Hard lump that moves
Possible cause: Skin cyst

Lump: Hard, painful lump with a high temperature
Possible cause: Skin abscess

Lumps on the armpit, neck or groin

Lump: Swelling on the side of the neck, armpit or groin
Possible cause: Swollen gland

Lump: Lump in the groin
Possible cause: Hernia

Lump: Lump on the front of the neck
Possible cause: Goitre

Lump: Fleshy growths around the groin
Possible cause: Genital warts

Lump: Swelling on the side of the neck, armpit or groin that does not go down
Possible cause: Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

Lumps around the bottom

Lump: Lump or lumps around the bottom (anus), often with itching or pain
Possible cause: Piles

Lump: Lump on the bottom (anus) and the need to do a poo
Possible cause: Rectal prolapse

Lump on the breast or testicle

Lump: Lump or swelling on the breasts
Find out more: Breast lumps

Lump: Lump or swelling on the testicles
Find out more: Testicle lumps

Lump on the hands

Lump: Smooth lump on the hand, wrist or finger
Possible cause: Ganglion cyst

Lump: Rough growth on the hand or finger
Possible cause: Wart

{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Skin cyst", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Skin cyst", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about skin cysts, which are fluid-filled lumps underneath the skin. They're common and harmless, and may disappear without treatment. Holding a warm flannel against the cyst can help it heal.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/skin-cyst/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-04-15T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-04-15T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/skin-cyst/", "name": "Skin cyst", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2021-01-27T17:02:39+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/skin-cyst/#overview", "description": "A skin cyst is a lump under the skin caused by a build-up of fluid.", "text": "

A skin cyst looks like a round lump just under the skin. They can range in size from smaller than a pea to a few centimetres wide.

Most cysts can be left alone. You can use a warm flannel to help it shrink. If the cyst is infected, you may need antibiotics.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/skin-cyst/#symptoms", "description": "A skin cyst looks like a round lump just under the skin. They can range in size from smaller than a pea to a few centimetres wide.", "text": "

A skin cyst is a round, dome-shaped lump. It's yellow or white, often with a small dark plug through which you might be able to squeeze out pus.

Cysts can range in size from smaller than a pea to a few centimetres across. They grow slowly.

Skin cysts do not usually hurt, but can become tender, sore and red if they become infected.

Foul-smelling pus coming out of the cyst is another sign of infection.

", "title": "What a cyst looks like"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/skin-cyst/#treatments-summary", "description": "Most cysts can be left alone. You can use a warm flannel to help it shrink. If the cyst is infected, you may need antibiotics.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/skin-cyst/#self-care", "description": "Most cysts can be left alone. You can use a warm flannel to help it shrink. If the cyst is infected, you may need antibiotics.", "text": "

Cysts are usually harmless. Small cysts that are not causing any problems can be left alone.

Holding a warm flannel against the skin will encourage the cyst to heal and reduce any inflammation.

Do not be tempted to burst the cyst. If it's infected, you risk spreading the infection, and\u00a0it can grow back if the sac is left underneath the skin.

", "title": "What you can do if you have a skin cyst"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/skin-cyst/#treatments-other", "description": "Most cysts can be left alone. You can use a warm flannel to help it shrink. If the cyst is infected, you may need antibiotics.", "text": "

See a GP if you think the cyst is infected. You may need a course of antibiotics.

Although some GP surgeries have minor surgery facilities, most do not remove cysts. You may be referred to a specialist, or you could pay for private treatment.

During a cyst removal, a local anaesthetic is used to numb the skin. A tiny cut is made in the skin and the cyst is squeezed out.

This procedure will leave a scar. The cyst\u00a0may also grow back, particularly if it was removed from the scalp or scrotum.

", "title": "Treatment for a skin cyst from a GP"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/skin-cyst/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Skin cyst"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A skin cyst is a fluid-filled lump just underneath the skin. It's common and harmless, and may disappear without treatment.

It can be difficult to tell whether a lump is a cyst or something else that might need treatment.

You should therefore see a GP if you have any sort of lump so it can be properly diagnosed.

Cysts are sometimes confused with\u00a0boils or skin abscesses.

Boils and abscesses are painful collections of pus that are caused by bacterial infections. A cyst may go on to become a boil or abscess.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "What a cyst looks like", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A skin cyst is a round, dome-shaped lump. It's yellow or white, often with a small dark plug through which you might be able to squeeze out pus.

Cysts can range in size from smaller than a pea to a few centimetres across. They grow slowly.

Skin cysts do not usually hurt, but can become tender, sore and red if they become infected.

Foul-smelling pus coming out of the cyst is another sign of infection.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Types of skin cyst", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Epidermoid cysts (one of the main types) are commonly found on the face,\u00a0neck,\u00a0chest, shoulders or skin around the\u00a0genitals.

They affect young and middle-aged adults, and are particularly common in people with acne. They do not usually run in families.

Cysts that form around hair follicles are known as pilar cysts. They're often found on the scalp.

Pilar cysts typically\u00a0affect middle-aged adults, mostly women. Unlike epidermoid cysts, they run in families.

A cyst that forms on the eyelid is called a chalazion or meibomian cyst.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Why do cysts form?", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Some of the cells in the top layer of skin produce keratin, a protein that gives skin its strength and flexibility.

Normally, these cells move up\u00a0to the surface of the skin as they start to die so they can be shed.

But the cells sometimes move deeper into the skin and multiply, forming a sac.

They secrete keratin into the middle of the sac, which forms a\u00a0thick, yellow paste. This can ooze out of the cyst if it's burst.

Anyone can develop a skin cyst, but you're more likely to have one if you've been through puberty, you have a history of acne, or you've injured the skin\u00a0(for example, if you've damaged a hair follicle).

Skin cysts are not contagious.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "What you can do if you have a skin cyst", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Cysts are usually harmless. Small cysts that are not causing any problems can be left alone.

Holding a warm flannel against the skin will encourage the cyst to heal and reduce any inflammation.

Do not be tempted to burst the cyst. If it's infected, you risk spreading the infection, and\u00a0it can grow back if the sac is left underneath the skin.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatment for a skin cyst from a GP", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

See a GP if you think the cyst is infected. You may need a course of antibiotics.

Although some GP surgeries have minor surgery facilities, most do not remove cysts. You may be referred to a specialist, or you could pay for private treatment.

During a cyst removal, a local anaesthetic is used to numb the skin. A tiny cut is made in the skin and the cyst is squeezed out.

This procedure will leave a scar. The cyst\u00a0may also grow back, particularly if it was removed from the scalp or scrotum.

Pins and needles:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Pins and needles", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Pins and needles", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about pins and needles (paraesthesia), a pricking, burning, tingling or numbing sensation that's usually felt in the arms, legs, hands or feet.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/pins-and-needles/", "lastReviewed": ["2021-01-18T00:00:00+00:00", "2024-01-18T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/pins-and-needles/", "name": "Pins and needles", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2021-01-27T14:22:25+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/pins-and-needles/#overview", "description": "Pins and needles is pricking, tingling or numbness on the skin. Everyone can get it but see a GP if you keep getting it or it lasts a long time.", "text": "

Pins and needles is usually caused by sitting or sleeping on part of your body. Sometimes it can be caused by conditions such as diabetes or sciatica.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "nonurgent_medical_help", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/pins-and-needles/#non-urgent-medical-help", "description": "", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • you constantly have pins and needles
  • it keeps coming back

Any treatment you might need for pins and needles will depend on the cause.

", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/pins-and-needles/#causes", "description": "Pins and needles is usually caused by sitting or sleeping on part of your body. Sometimes it can be caused by conditions such as diabetes or sciatica.", "text": "

There are some possible medical causes of pins and needles. If you have other symptoms this might help to find the cause.

But do not self-diagnose – see a GP if you're worried.

Symptoms: Pins and needles, pain or numbness in hands and feet
Possible condition: Diabetes

Symptoms: Pins and needles in fingers or toes that change colour
Possible condition: Raynaud's

Symptoms: Breathing too quickly, trembling hands, pins and needles
Possible condition: Hyperventilation

Symptoms: Pain and pins and needles that travels from your back, down your leg to your foot
Possible condition: Sciatica

Symptoms: Pins and needles in different parts of your body
Possible condition: Multiple sclerosis

Long-lasting pins and needles may also be caused by:

  • treatments – such as chemotherapy
  • some medicines – such as HIV medicine, medicine to prevent seizures, or some antibiotics
  • toxic substances – such as lead or radiation
  • poor diet
  • a trapped nerve in your back or neck
  • nerve damage – after an injury or illness
  • drinking too much alcohol

Pins and needles feels like pricking, tingling or numbness on the skin.

It happens when the blood supply to the nerves is cut off. This is usually when you sit or sleep on part of your body. It only lasts a few minutes.

You often get pins and needles in your:

  • arms
  • hands
  • legs
  • feet

It usually stops when the weight is taken off the body part and your blood supply returns to the nerves.

Most coughs are caused by a cold or flu. Other causes include smoking, heartburn (acid reflux), allergies and infections like bronchitis.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/cough/#self-care", "description": "You can treat a cough yourself. Rest and drink plenty of fluids. You could also try hot lemon and honey (not suitable for babies under 1 year old).", "text": "

There's usually no need to see a GP.

You should:

  • rest
  • drink plenty of fluids

You could also try:

  • paracetamol or ibuprofen to treat any pain
  • hot lemon and honey (not suitable for babies under 1 year old)
  • a herbal medicine called pelargonium (suitable for people aged 12 or over)

But there's limited evidence to show these work.

How to make a hot lemon and honey drink
  1. Squeeze half a lemon into a mug of boiled water.
  2. Add 1 to 2 teaspoons of honey.
  3. Drink while still warm (do not give hot drinks to small children).

Hot lemon with honey has a similar effect to cough medicines.

These will not stop your cough, but may help you cough less.", "text": "

If you have a cough, you can ask a pharmacist about:

  • cough syrup
  • cough medicine (some cough medicines should not be given to children under 12)
  • cough sweets

These will not stop your cough, but may help you cough less.

Decongestants and cough medicines containing codeine will not stop your cough.

Call a pharmacy or contact them online before going in person. You can get medicines delivered or ask someone to collect them.

Find a pharmacy

See a GP if:

  • you've had a cough for more than 3 weeks (persistent cough)
  • your cough is very bad or quickly gets worse \u2013 for example, you have a hacking cough or cannot stop coughing
  • you feel very unwell
  • you have chest pain
  • you're losing weight for no reason
  • the side of your neck feels swollen and painful (swollen glands)
  • you find it hard to breathe
  • you have a weakened immune system \u2013 for example, because of chemotherapy or diabetes

See a GP urgently if you're coughing up blood.

To find out what's causing your cough, the GP might:

  • take a sample of any mucus you might be coughing up
  • order an X-ray, allergy test, or a test to see how well your lungs work
  • refer you to hospital to see a specialist, but this is rare

Most coughs are caused by a cold or flu.

Other causes include:

  • smoking
  • heartburn (acid reflux)
  • allergies \u2013 for example, hay fever
  • infections like bronchitis
  • mucus dripping down the throat from the back of the nose

A cough is rarely a sign of something serious like lung cancer.

There are many possible causes of knee pain, including a sprain or strain, tendonitis, cartilage damage, arthritis and gout.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/knee-pain/#self-care", "description": "To ease knee pain and swelling, avoid putting weight on your knee, use an ice pack for up to 20 minutes every 2 to 3 hours, and take paracetamol.", "text": "

Try these things at first:

  • put as little weight as possible on your knee – for example, avoid standing for a long time
  • use an ice pack (or bag of frozen peas wrapped in a tea towel) on your knee for up to 20 minutes every 2 to 3 hours
  • take paracetamol
", "title": "How to ease knee pain and swelling"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "nonurgent_medical_help", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/knee-pain/#non-urgent-medical-help", "description": "", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • your knee pain does not improve within a few weeks
  • your knee locks, painfully clicks or gives way – painless clicking is normal

Get advice from 111 now if:

  • your knee is very painful
  • you cannot move your knee or put any weight on it
  • your knee is badly swollen or has changed shape
  • you have a very high temperature, feel hot and shivery, and have redness or heat around your knee – this can be a sign of infection

111 will tell you what to do. They can tell you the right place to get help if you need to see someone.

Go to 111.nhs.uk or call 111.

Other ways to get help

Go to an urgent treatment centre

You can also go to an urgent treatment centre if you need to see someone now.

They're also called walk-in centres or minor injuries units.

You may be seen quicker than you would at A&E.

Find an urgent treatment centre

", "title": "Treatment from a GP"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/knee-pain/#causes", "description": "There are many possible causes of knee pain, including a sprain or strain, tendonitis, cartilage damage, arthritis and gout.", "text": "

Knee pain can be a symptom of many different conditions.

This information might give you an idea of what the cause might be. But do not self-diagnose – see a GP if you're worried.

Knee pain after an injury

Knee symptoms: Pain after overstretching, overusing or twisting, often during exercise
Possible cause: Sprains and strains

Knee symptoms: Pain between your kneecap and shin, often caused by repetitive running or jumping
Possible cause: Tendonitis

Knee symptoms: Unstable, gives way when you try to stand, unable to straighten, may hear a popping sound during injury
Possible cause: Torn ligament, tendon or meniscus, cartilage damage

Knee symptoms: Teenagers and young adults with pain and swelling below kneecap
Possible cause: Osgood-Schlatter's disease

Knee symptoms: Kneecap changes shape after a collision or sudden change in direction
Possible cause: Dislocated kneecap

Knee pain with no obvious injury

Knee symptoms: Pain and stiffness in both knees, mild swelling, more common in older people
Possible cause: Osteoarthritis

Knee symptoms: Warm and red, kneeling or bending makes pain and swelling worse
Possible cause: Bursitis

Knee symptoms: Swelling, warmth, bruising, more likely while taking anticoagulants
Possible cause: Bleeding in the joint

Knee symptoms: Hot and red, sudden attacks of very bad pain
Possible cause: Gout or septic arthritis

Nosebleed:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Nosebleed", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Nosebleed", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about the causes of nosebleeds, how to treat them at home and when you should get medical advice.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/nosebleed/", "lastReviewed": ["2021-01-22T00:00:00+00:00", "2024-01-22T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/nosebleed/", "name": "Nosebleed", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2021-01-27T09:54:07+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/nosebleed/#overview", "description": "Nosebleeds are not usually a sign of anything serious. They're common, particularly in children, and most can be easily treated at home.", "text": "

Nosebleeds can have many possible causes including picking your nose, blowing your nose too hard, and an injury such as a broken nose.

To avoid having another nosebleed, try not to blow or pick your nose, drink hot drinks or alcohol, or do any strenuous activity for 24 hours.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "nonurgent_medical_help", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/nosebleed/#non-urgent-medical-help", "description": "", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • a child under 2 years old has a nosebleed
  • you have regular nosebleeds
  • you have symptoms of anaemia \u2013 such as a faster heartbeat (palpitations), shortness of breath and pale skin
  • you're taking a blood-thinning medicine, such as warfarin
  • you have a condition that means your blood cannot clot properly, such as haemophilia

The GP might want to test you for haemophilia or for other conditions like anaemia.

Go to A&E if:

  • your nosebleed lasts longer than 10 to 15 minutes
  • the bleeding seems excessive
  • you're swallowing a large amount of blood that makes you vomit
  • the bleeding started after a blow to your head
  • you're feeling weak or dizzy
  • you're having difficulty breathing
", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/nosebleed/#causes", "description": "Nosebleeds can have many possible causes including picking your nose, blowing your nose too hard, and an injury such as a broken nose.", "text": "

The inside of the nose is delicate and nosebleeds happen when it's damaged. This can be caused by:

  • picking your nose
  • blowing your nose too hard
  • the inside of your nose being too dry (maybe because of a change in air temperature)

Nosebleeds that need medical attention can come from deeper inside the nose and usually affect adults. They can be caused by:

  • an injury or broken nose
  • high blood pressure
  • conditions that affect the blood vessels or how the blood clots
  • certain medicines, like warfarin

Sometimes the cause of a nosebleed is unknown.

Certain people are more prone to getting nosebleeds, including:

  • children (they usually grow out of them by 11)
  • elderly people
  • pregnant women
", "title": "Causes of a nosebleed"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/nosebleed/#self-care", "description": "If you have a nosebleed, sit down and lean forward with your head tilted forward. Pinch your nose just above your nostrils for 10 to 15 minutes.", "text": "

If you have a nosebleed, you should:

  • sit down and lean forward, with your head tilted forward
  • pinch your nose just above your nostrils for 10 to 15 minutes
  • breathe through your mouth

Holding an icepack (or a bag of frozen peas wrapped in a tea towel) on the top of the nose may help reduce the blood flow. But the evidence to show it works is not very strong.

", "title": "How to stop a nosebleed yourself"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/nosebleed/#treatments-other", "description": "If you have a severe nosebleed, a doctor may stop the bleeding using a stick with a chemical on it or by packing your nose with sponges.", "text": "

If doctors can see where the blood is coming from, they may seal it by pressing a stick with a chemical on it to stop the bleeding.

If this is not possible, doctors might pack your nose with sponges to stop the bleeding. You may need to stay in hospital for a day or two.

", "title": "Hospital treatment for nosebleeds"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "prevention", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/nosebleed/#prevention", "description": "To avoid having another nosebleed, try not to blow or pick your nose, drink hot drinks or alcohol, or do any strenuous activity for 24 hours.", "text": "

After a nosebleed, for 24 hours try not to:

  • blow your nose
  • pick your nose
  • drink hot drinks or alcohol
  • do any heavy lifting or strenuous exercise
  • pick any scabs
", "title": "When a nosebleed stops"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/nosebleed/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Nosebleed"}], "keywords": ["Nosebleeds", "Hypertension"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Nosebleeds are not usually a sign of anything serious. They're common, particularly in children, and most can be easily treated at home.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • a child under 2 years old has a nosebleed
  • you have regular nosebleeds
  • you have symptoms of anaemia \u2013 such as a faster heartbeat (palpitations), shortness of breath and pale skin
  • you're taking a blood-thinning medicine, such as warfarin
  • you have a condition that means your blood cannot clot properly, such as haemophilia

The GP might want to test you for haemophilia or for other conditions like anaemia.

"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Emergency", "identifier": "5", "text": "

Go to A&E if:

  • your nosebleed lasts longer than 10 to 15 minutes
  • the bleeding seems excessive
  • you're swallowing a large amount of blood that makes you vomit
  • the bleeding started after a blow to your head
  • you're feeling weak or dizzy
  • you're having difficulty breathing
"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Causes of a nosebleed", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The inside of the nose is delicate and nosebleeds happen when it's damaged. This can be caused by:

  • picking your nose
  • blowing your nose too hard
  • the inside of your nose being too dry (maybe because of a change in air temperature)

Nosebleeds that need medical attention can come from deeper inside the nose and usually affect adults. They can be caused by:

  • an injury or broken nose
  • high blood pressure
  • conditions that affect the blood vessels or how the blood clots
  • certain medicines, like warfarin

Sometimes the cause of a nosebleed is unknown.

Certain people are more prone to getting nosebleeds, including:

  • children (they usually grow out of them by 11)
  • elderly people
  • pregnant women
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How to stop a nosebleed yourself", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

If you have a nosebleed, you should:

  • sit down and lean forward, with your head tilted forward
  • pinch your nose just above your nostrils for 10 to 15 minutes
  • breathe through your mouth

Holding an icepack (or a bag of frozen peas wrapped in a tea towel) on the top of the nose may help reduce the blood flow. But the evidence to show it works is not very strong.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"@type": "VideoObject", "name": "How to treat a nosebleed", "embedUrl": "//players.brightcove.net/79855382001/WwRvWyF4zr_default/index.html?videoId=5712761714001", "content_url": "https://manifest.prod.boltdns.net/manifest/v1/hls/v4/clear/79855382001/e616002b-7fb2-4b18-8d75-745670843617/10s/master.m3u8?fastly_token=NWZmY2FhNmRfYjM4NjQ1M2Q0MjRlYzRiYjlhYjJjMjc0OGY4NTRhZTBmMjdmNjUxOTI4MDQ0MzEwMzFhYTQ0NTQyYjQxOTQ4NQ%3D%3D", "duration": "PT37.867S", "position": 1, "identifier": "14", "alternateName": "5712761714001", "description": "This video shows you how to treat a nosebleed.", "uploadDate": "2020-12-09T00:04:56.003000+00:00", "lastReviewed": ["2017-06-05", "2020-06-05"], "thumbnailUrl": "https://cf-images.eu-west-1.prod.boltdns.net/v1/static/79855382001/e616002b-7fb2-4b18-8d75-745670843617/6c791b73-4790-494c-82d5-5d34f65c9a77/160x90/match/image.jpg", "text": ""}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Hospital treatment for nosebleeds", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

If doctors can see where the blood is coming from, they may seal it by pressing a stick with a chemical on it to stop the bleeding.

If this is not possible, doctors might pack your nose with sponges to stop the bleeding. You may need to stay in hospital for a day or two.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "When a nosebleed stops", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

After a nosebleed, for 24 hours try not to:

  • blow your nose
  • pick your nose
  • drink hot drinks or alcohol
  • do any heavy lifting or strenuous exercise
  • pick any scabs

But it might be a sign of a problem like an infection if it looks, feels or smells different to usual.", "text": "

Vaginal discharge is usually clear and does not have a strong smell. You might have an infection if your usual discharge changes appearance or smell.

Common causes of unusual vaginal discharge include bacterial vaginosis, thrush and sexually transmitted infections like chlamydia.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginal-discharge/#symptoms", "description": "Vaginal discharge is usually clear and does not have a strong smell. You might have an infection if your usual discharge changes appearance or smell.", "text": "

Vaginal discharge is not usually anything to worry about if it:

  • does not have a strong or unpleasant smell
  • is clear or white
  • is thick and sticky
  • is slippery and wet

You can get vaginal discharge at any age.

The amount of discharge varies. You usually get heavier discharge during pregnancy, if you're sexually active or if you're using birth control. It's often slippery and wet for a few days between your periods (when you ovulate).

", "title": "Check if your vaginal discharge is normal"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginal-discharge/#causes", "description": "Common causes of unusual vaginal discharge include bacterial vaginosis, thrush and sexually transmitted infections like chlamydia.", "text": "

If your discharge changes – for example, in smell, colour or texture – it might be a sign of an infection. But do not self-diagnose – see a GP if you're worried.

Discharge: Smells fishy
Possible cause: Bacterial vaginosis

Discharge: Thick and white, like cottage cheese
Possible cause: Thrush

Discharge: Green, yellow or frothy
Possible cause: Trichomoniasis

Discharge: With pelvic pain or bleeding
Possible cause: Chlamydia or gonorrhoea

Discharge: With blisters or sores
Possible cause: Genital herpes

", "title": "When vaginal discharge can be a sign of an infection"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "nonurgent_medical_help", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginal-discharge/#non-urgent-medical-help", "description": "", "text": "

See a GP or go to a sexual health clinic if:

  • your vaginal discharge changes colour, smell or texture
  • you produce more discharge than usual
  • you feel itchy or sore
  • you bleed between periods or after sex
  • you get pain when peeing
  • you get pain in the area between your tummy and thighs (pelvic pain)

Sexual health clinics can help with abnormal discharge

Sexual health clinics treat problems with the genitals and urine system.

Many sexual health clinics offer a walk-in service, where you do not need an appointment. They'll often get test results quicker than GP surgeries.

Find a sexual health clinic

", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "self_care", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vaginal-discharge/#self-care", "description": "If you have a lot of vaginal discharge, using panty liners can help. Wash the skin around your vagina gently with plain water to avoid irritation.", "text": "

You cannot prevent vaginal discharge.

Panty liners can help with heavy or excessive discharge or if you're worried about any smell. But do not use them all of the time because they can cause irritation.

To help avoid irritation, soreness or dryness:


Do

  • wash the skin around your vagina gently using plain water


Don't

  • do not use perfumed or non-perfumed soaps or gels

  • do not use deodorants or scented hygiene wipes

  • do not wash inside your vagina (douche)

{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Night sweats", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Night sweats", "alternateName": ["Sweating at night"]}, "description": "Find out about night sweats, including what they are and what might be causing them, and when to get medical help.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/night-sweats/", "lastReviewed": ["2021-01-12T00:00:00+00:00", "2024-01-12T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/night-sweats/", "name": "Night sweats", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2021-01-26T14:50:55+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/night-sweats/#overview", "description": "", "text": "

Night sweats are when you sweat so much that your night clothes and bedding get soaking wet.

Common causes of night sweats include the menopause, anxiety, medicines, low blood sugar, alcohol or drug use, and excessive sweating (hyperhidrosis).

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/night-sweats/#symptoms", "description": "Night sweats are when you sweat so much that your night clothes and bedding get soaking wet.", "text": "

It's normal to sweat during the night if the room or your bedding is making you too hot.

Night sweats are when you sweat so much that your night clothes and bedding are soaking wet, even though where you're sleeping is cool.

Adults and children can get night sweats.

", "title": "What night sweats are"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "nonurgent_medical_help", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/night-sweats/#non-urgent-medical-help", "description": "Treatment is not usually needed for night sweats. If you have night sweats, you will not usually need treatment, but the GP will want to check if you have any other symptoms.

If you're taking medicine and the GP thinks it might be causing night sweats, they may prescribe a different one.

", "title": "Treatment from a GP"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/night-sweats/#causes", "description": "Common causes of night sweats include the menopause, anxiety, medicines, low blood sugar, alcohol or drug use, and excessive sweating (hyperhidrosis).", "text": "

The most common reasons for night sweats are:

  • menopause symptoms (\"hot flushes\")
  • anxiety
  • medicines \u2013 some antidepressants, steroids and painkillers
  • low blood sugar (hypoglycaemia)
  • alcohol or drug use
  • a harmless condition called hyperhidrosis that makes you sweat too much all the time

Sometimes the cause of night sweats is unknown.

Priapism (painful erections):
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Priapism (painful erections)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Priapism (painful erections)", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Read about priapism, a persistent, often painful erection. If it lasts for more than 2 hours, go to A&E to prevent permanent damage.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/priapism-painful-erections/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-12-22T00:00:00+00:00", "2023-12-22T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/priapism-painful-erections/", "name": "Priapism (painful erections)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2021-01-25T13:37:27+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/priapism-painful-erections/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Priapism (painful erections)"}], "keywords": ["Priapism"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Priapism is a long-lasting painful erection. It can cause permanent damage to your penis if not treated quickly.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Things you can try", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Things you can try yourself

Priapism may get better on its own within 2 hours.

There are things you can try to reduce your erection.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Do

  • try to go for a pee

  • have a warm bath or shower

  • drink lots of water

  • go for a gentle walk

  • try exercises, such as squats or running on the spot

  • take painkillers like paracetamol if you need to

"}, {"position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Do/Don't", "identifier": "9", "text": "

Don't

  • do not apply ice packs or cold water to your penis \u2013 this can make things worse

  • do not have sex or masturbate \u2013 it will not make your erection go away

  • do not drink alcohol

  • do not smoke

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Emergency", "identifier": "5", "text": "

Call 999 or go to A&E if you have an erection that lasts more than 2 hours

An erection that lasts this long needs to be treated in hospital as soon as possible to help avoid permanent damage to the penis.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treatment in hospital", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Hospital treatment for priapism

Treatments to help reduce your erection include:

  • tablets or injections directly into your penis
  • using a needle to drain blood from your penis, done while the area is numbed under local anaesthetic
  • surgery to drain the blood through a tiny cut, done while you're asleep under general anaesthetic
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of priapism

Priapism most commonly affects people with sickle cell disease.

Less common causes include:

  • blood-thinning medicines, like warfarin
  • some antidepressants
  • recreational drugs, like cannabis and cocaine
  • some medicines for high blood pressure
  • other blood disorders, like thalassaemia and leukaemia
  • some treatments for erection problems
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}

Cataracts are when the lens, a small transparent disc inside your eye, develops cloudy patches.

Over time these patches usually become bigger causing blurry, misty vision and eventually blindness.

When we're young, our lenses are usually like clear glass, allowing us to see through them. As we get older, they start to become frosted, like bathroom glass, and begin to limit our vision.

Cataracts usually appear in both eyes. They may not necessarily develop at the same time or be the same in each eye.

They're more common in older adults and can affect your ability to carry out daily activities such as driving.

Cataracts can also affect babies and young children.

Read\u00a0more about childhood cataracts

When to seek medical advice

You should see an optician if you have any of these symptoms:

  • your eyesight is blurred or misty
  • you find lights too bright or glaring
  • you find it harder to see in low light
  • colours look faded

If you wear glasses, you may feel your lenses are dirty and need cleaning, even when they do not.

Cataracts are not usually painful and do not make your eyes red or irritated, but they can be painful if they're in an advanced stage or if you've got another eye condition.

Testing for age-related cataracts

An optician will do a series of eye tests, including a visual acuity exam, which measures how well you see at various distances.

If the optician thinks you have cataracts, you may be referred to an eye specialist (ophthalmologist) for more tests and treatment.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Treating age-related cataracts", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treating age-related cataracts

If your cataracts are not too bad, stronger glasses and brighter reading lights may help for a while.

But cataracts get worse over time, so you'll eventually need surgery to remove and replace the affected lens.

Surgery is the only treatment that's proven to be effective for cataracts.

Read about cataract surgery

Driving and cataracts

If you have cataracts, it could affect your ability to drive.

You do not need to tell the DVLA if you have (or previously had) cataracts and you still meet the visual standards for driving.

If you drive a bus, coach or lorry, you do not need to tell the DVLA if you have (or previously had) cataracts and:

  • you still meet the visual standards for driving
  • you do not have an increased sensitivity to glare because of the cataract

Read about cataracts and driving on the GOV.UK website

What causes age-related cataracts?

It's not entirely clear why we're more likely to develop cataracts as we get older, but some things may increase your risk of cataracts, including:

  • a family history of cataracts
  • smoking
  • diabetes
  • eye injury
  • long-term use of steroids
  • drinking too much alcohol
